ANTH 288/ LCD288. Voices of New York.
Justification: To offer a course which combines analytical and research traditions from Anthropology and Linguistics which will focus on current language use and attitudes in New York and the U.S., and stress the development of skills in research design, analysis, and social scientific writing.  It will also add a U.S. area course to our curricula, which is focused on language issues.

AII.5A.2         Anthropology (06-14, approved by Academic Senate 9/14/06)
ANTH 247.  Archaeology of Ireland.
3 hr.: 3 cr.  Prereq.: English 110.  Six credits in social science or sophomore standing.
Prereq.: English 110.  Six credits in social science or sophomore standing.
Six credits in social science or sophomore standing.
The development of Irish society from the initial settlement by foraging peoples through the development of agriculture and metallurgy to the origins of chiefdoms and states.  Special attention is given to the Celtic Iron Age Society.
Justification: Archaeology of Ireland has been taught twice under the Anthropology 290W listing (special topics).   The department  would like to establish the course as a regularly listed course. The course would be taught every other spring, alternating with the existing Anthropology 242W:  Archaeology of Europe.  The curricular contribution of this series consists of the application of anthropological concepts, methods and theories to the analysis change and stability of a specific cultural tradition.
The course is also part of the Irish Studies Program.  It is the only course dealing with Irish prehistory, and offers a bridge between the sagas and the historic period. This course will be proposed as a W course.
title: Archaeology of Ireland

description: A historical examination of how, and why, the United States became involved in Vietnam during the second half of the twentieth century.  Examines American foreign policy in Vietnam, the domestic impact of the war, movements against the war, and how race, class, and gender informed the composition of the armed forces, as well as larger questions related to issues such as nationalism, patriotism, dissent, and power.
justification: The impact of the Vietnam War on American society and the place of the war in American foreign policy continue to be the subjects of historical research and debate.  It is important that students have an opportunity to explore the critical issues that the war raised. This course has been offered successfully as a History 200 Special Topics course.

AII.5B.1 Earth & Environmental Sciences (G06-42, approved by Academic Senate 10/12/06)
GEOL 552. GLOBE
®
Program Environmental research.  3 hrs.; 3 cr. Prereq.: Open to pre-service graduate students and in-service secondary school teachers; not open to students who have completed GEOL 551.
Prereq.: Open to pre-service graduate students and in-service secondary school teachers; not open to students who have completed GEOL 551.
Research into selected local environmental issues using GLOBE
®
Program protocols for atmosphere, soil, hydrology, seasonal change, and land cover. Course includes GLOBE
®
Program teacher certification. Includes 3 all-day field exercises.
Rationale: This course is intended for Secondary Education MS Ed and pre-service teachers specializing in Science and Technology.  Like its companion course (GEOL 551) designed for Elementary Education students, it uses the international GLOBE Program protocols to study the environment and integrate principles and practices from the physical sciences. During initial training in the GLOBE protocols and web-based database, students will use those protocols to design and conduct research projects that examine the local environment at their schools or on the Queens College campus. The second half of the course is devoted to group research projects in topics selected by the students in consultation with the instructor.
Participants in this course model what their own students will do; once certified as GLOBE teachers, participants will use the same techniques and protocols in their classes and enrichment activities, and join the schools and environmental centers of the NY metropolitan area GLOBE community.
This course complements a series of 500-level Geology courses for teachers and the recently initiated Advanced Graduate Certificate in Earth Science. It also furthers the aims of the College’s Partnership in the GLOBE Program, now in its fourth year of full operation. By June, 2005, this partnership (GLOBE NY Metro) will have trained nearly 700 teachers from 300 schools.
In order to certify participants as GLOBE teachers, the instructor of the course will be a certified GLOBE Teacher Trainer.
AIII – 5A.1
Exchange Agreement with the Universita’ degli Studi di Catania, Italy
RESOLVED:  That the Board of Trustees of The City University of New York (CUNY) authorize the President of Queens College to execute an international agreement on behalf of Queens College and the John D. Calandra Italian American Institute with the Universita’ degli Studi di Catania, to enable CUNY students enrolled in the CUNY/ITALY Exchange Program to study at the Universita’ degli Studi di Catania and the Universita’ degli Studi di Catania students to study at CUNY.  Neither party to this agreement is obligated to pay any monetary consideration to the other.  The agreement is for a one year period beginning in September 1, 2006 to August 31, 2007 and shall include up to two two-year options for the College to renew in its best interest.  The agreement shall be subject to approval as to form by the University Office of General Counsel.
EXPLANATION:   This Agreement will allow an exchange of students from The City University of New York (CUNY) and the Universita’ degli Studi di Catania, in Italy.  The equivalent of two (2) students per institution per academic year are expected to participate.

RESOLVED:  That the Board of Trustees of The City University of New York authorize the President of Queens College to execute an  international Study Abroad agreement on behalf of Queens College with Universidad de Valladolid, Spain, to enable students enrolled in the College’s Education Abroad program to study liberal arts courses including Spanish language, literature, culture, art and music.  Other than the transmission of student fees by the College to Universidad de Valladolid, neither party to this agreement is obligated to pay any monetary consideration to the other.  The agreement is for a one-year period and shall include up to two two-year options for the College to renew in its best interest.  This program will begin January 1, 2007. EXPLANATION:  CUNY students in the Queens College Education Abroad program will be able to attend Universidad de Valladolid and take courses that are pre-approved by Queens College.  Approximately 60 CUNY students will participate in this program each academic year.
